# 2025-09-01 07:34 gav: Toaster access should come once it’s clear that M2 is there or at least when we’re confident that M2 could pass. I’d like to start accepting M1 candidates imminently, but it’s really on davxyto determine when the fuzzer is ready for prime time.
# 2025-09-01 07:36 gav: M2 candidates should begin being accepted once we have the conformance tests for that. The priority is M1 testing for now.
# 2025-09-01 07:54 gav: Obviously nothing stops this community from setting up their own comparator harness and get going with cross-impl refinement testing/fuzzing.
# 2025-09-02 03:46 jan: Considering it's still incomplete and the spec is not at 1.0 yet - nope. There's still the new gas cost model that will be introduced (there is a high chance that it will require a competent SIMD-accelerated codepath to reach M3/M4), there could be minor changes to the instruction set to accelerate things and I still want to use more aggressive SIMD acceleration in certain places of the codebase. For everyone wondering about M3 and M4, in general you can expect the following to be tested at M3 and M4 when it comes to PVM: - Recompilation speed - how fast can you recompile code into native code? - Gas cost calculation speed - how fast can you calculate the gas costs for blocks? (This will not be tested separately from the recompilation speed, but I'm explicitly mentioning it since I expect it will also be a major factor.) - Execution performance - how fast is the code that you've recompiled? - Gas costs conformance - is the native code you've emitted conformant with the gas cost model? The new gas cost model will be somewhat strict wrt what exact machine code you can emit to avoid denial-of-service type of attacks; for example, whatever machine code you'll emit for the PVM addition instruction will be _required_ to only have a single cycle of latency, so essentially the _only_ valid way of recompiling it will be into a single native addition instruction. The GP of course won't tell you explicitly which native instructions are conformant with given latency numbers (that would be widely out-of-scope for the GP), but once we get up to M3 I might write up an implementers' note or host another talk or something like that for people to give a little bit of guidance as to how to actually do it in practice without having a PhD in CPU microarchitecture. (edited)
# 2025-09-02 03:53 jan: The PVM code blob is not a single big function. It's split into basic blocks which in theory should be recompilable in isolation if that's what you want to do, so a more explicit subdivision of the code blob wouldn't necessarily help you all that much. (Side note: of course, if someone has good ideas to speed things up/make things more efficient/simplify things without compromising on speed then I'm always happy to hear any potential ideas.) (edited)
# 2025-09-02 03:55 xlchen: what are the benefits to put everything into a single blob compare to one blob per entry point? (it is simpler for one)
# 2025-09-02 03:57 jan: Practical benefits besides simplicity? You can share code between the blobs, I suppose.
# 2025-09-02 04:00 jan: In general since you could most likely just cache and reuse the recompiled PVM binary based on a hash you know a priori for the toplevel services it's probably not worth splitting the blobs for each entry point.
# 2025-09-02 04:05 jan: But of course this doesn't apply to inner PVM. Those don't have any "official" entry points (whatever the toplevel service decides is the entry point will be the entry point), and you still need fast recompilation since for inner PVMs whatever service is invoking the inner PVM can just conjure whatever code blob it wants from wherever it wants, so near zero cost caching is not feasible there (you could do caching there if you'd calculate the hash yourself in your PVM, but considering it's possible to recompile the code faster than it is to hash it, it's not really the solution)
# 2025-09-02 05:25 clearloop: yes I think SIMD would help a lot! given we are generating thousands of write_bytes(addr, 4) atm for the testing programs in traces, my complaint about the program(blocks) (wait, ain't this a chain of blocks, e.g. blockchain ??) format is mainly about the compilation speed and the code size, mb concept like wasm module (reduce size) or function based cache (in compiler, speed up compilation) would help if all of the programs are sharing a same 1MB block area in their binaries and I agree with that the execution speed has more priority, since it's more hardcore in our implementations while cache stuffs are easy to be patched later then
# 2025-09-12 11:29 prematurata: am i wrong or someone had a ci pipeline to auto timestamp commits into polkadot? it seems i cant find it
# 2025-09-12 12:17 ascriv: https://github.com/JamBrains/remark-commit
# 2025-09-12 12:17 ascriv: @[Oliver Tale-Yazdi]
# 2025-09-12 12:23 vinsystems: It should be enough to push code to GitHub frequently, right?
# 2025-09-12 12:30 oliver.tale-yazdi: This was discussed many times now. The whole point is that teams need to present _unfakable timestamps_. Just pushing commits to GitHub _does not achieve this_, since you can force push with altered timestamps and change them to arbitrary values. Using Merge Requests does achieve this (if you trust GitHub), since GitHub merge requests are queryable into the past with fixed timestamps. Persisting the commit hashes and timestamps to a decentralizeed ledger achieves this as well without having to trust GitHub. (edited)
# 2025-09-12 12:31 oliver.tale-yazdi: Anyway, I am not a judge of the rules and this is my interpretation of it.
# 2025-09-12 12:36 vinsystems: The repository activity shows when the code has been pushed and each one of these timestamps are unfakeable. Perhaps a judge could help us clarify this. (edited)
# 2025-09-12 12:39 vinsystems: image.png
# 2025-09-12 12:42 oliver.tale-yazdi: I did not know this Activity feature of GitHub. Looks like that could work, yea
# 2025-09-12 12:56 ascriv: > <@vinsystems:matrix.org> Yes, but the activity of the repository shows when the code has been pushed and each one of these timestamps are unfakable. Perhaps a judge could help us clarify this. I received word from the fellowship that pushes to main, e.g. are technically not sufficient, but they will still consider my code. To be safe, just put timestamps on some blockchain
# 2025-09-12 12:57 ascriv: They said they will deprioritize my submission due to the extra work required for them to verify
# 2025-09-12 12:57 jaymansfield: GitHub workflow execution timestamps also can’t be modified if you have some type of CI setup to verify tests on merges for example.
# 2025-09-12 13:05 vinsystems: Acording to the rule 15, we should be safe pushing code to Github frequently. I didn't develop all the code in main, so far I have done 30 merges on GitHub, but acording to the rule 15 I thought that it was ok to conform to the rules. (edited)
# 2025-09-12 13:11 clearloop: truth, commits can be faked easily, but actions and PR histories can't
# 2025-09-12 13:16 ascriv: > <@vinsystems:matrix.org> Acording to the rule 15, we should be safe pushing code to Github frequently. I didn't develop all the code in main, I have done 30 merges so far on GitHub, but acording to the rule 15 I thought that it was ok to conform to the rules. This was also my argument as well. If you want confirmation, you can email jam@web3.foundation about your specific case. You should be fine but they might give you a similar answer
# 2025-09-12 17:37 sourabhniyogi: Can you offer your thoughts on whether one or more high-performance **PVM FFI-able libraries for JAM Implementers** can reasonably be used for M1/M2 unofficial vs official fuzzing? I drafted a pvm.h here https://github.com/davxy/jam-conformance/issues/76 as a solution to the "our impl performance is Nx slower than Polkajam 😂" problem (for high N 😅), which is very sharp for those in Set C + D, so far. The gorgeous JAM Conformance dashboard got us whipped into shape real fast, along with the fear of having ridiculously long audit times =). Many teams \[faced with the performance data pointing to slower audit times (weeks/months rather than hours/days)\] are going to want to go _hybrid_ by combining a PVM interpreter/recompiler written in a high performance language (probably C/C++/Rust) with their language. I think some sharpening on what is an acceptable way to go hybrid would be super useful! The "For the purpose of performance testing, a third-party PVM implementation may be used to help achieve the required performance." is already there for the "Non-PVM Validating Node Path". So I see no reason why, especially now that we have 15+ teams happily fuzzing, we should not expose a PVM API and some high performance PVM libraries conforming to this API, between Rust (specifically what polkajam uses) and C/X86 (from those gunning for M3/M4) at least. What do you think? (edited)
# 2025-09-12 17:51 dave: The web3 JAM page (https://jam.web3.foundation/) is fairly clear that an original PVM implementation is required for M1/M2. A third-party PVM implementation may only be used for MN3/MN4, to hit the required performance targets, if you are following the "non-PVM validating node path". So I think the answer is that no you can't use a third-party PVM implementation to improve your performance for M1/M2.
# 2025-09-12 17:56 dave: I wouldn't recommend trying to integrate a third-party PVM implementation now as I would think you could easily fall foul of the clean room requirements
# 2025-09-12 19:05 tomusdrw: Quote from jam.web3.foundation: > The language set of an implementation is determined as the language in which its business logic is written. Peripheral, performance-bottleneck components of an implementation may be written in a higher-performance language without any impact on the consideration of language set. A non-exhaustive list of such components include: **PVM**, Database, Erasure, (de-)coding Teams writing in "slow" languages, are not required to write PVM in the same language. I think the only point is that it should be original implementation for "Validating Node Path". (edited)
# 2025-09-12 19:26 jaymansfield: > <@tomusdrw:matrix.org> Quote from jam.web3.foundation: > > > The language set of an implementation is determined as the language in which its business logic is written. Peripheral, performance-bottleneck components of an implementation may be written in a higher-performance language without any impact on the consideration of language set. A non-exhaustive list of such components include: **PVM**, Database, Erasure, (de-)coding > > Teams writing in "slow" languages, are not required to write PVM in the same language. I think the only point is that it should be original implementation for "Validating Node Path". And in some languages it isn’t even possible to execute assembly to do a built in recompiler. I ended up doing a c++ recompiler for my java implementation.
# 2025-09-12 20:07 clearloop: interesting, I thought it would be into JAVA bytecode or Kotlin IR
# 2025-09-12 20:11 dave: Yeah your PVM impl doesn't need to be in the same language, but it does need to be _your_ implementation. It can't be a third-party implementation, at least for M1/M2.
# 2025-09-12 21:23 sourabhniyogi: There are now 15+ enrolled teams that already have their own first-party PVM interpreter happily getting fuzz-reports. The Set C/D teams happen to have slower implementations. But I don't think there is any value in these slow PVM interpreters _except_ for the fact that _they trained us_: everyone with this JAM experience can see this was mere scaffolding for the next stage, which is to replace all of this with a high performance PVM recompiler, which can be done with third-party PVM libraries. Re "Clean room": Multiple teams can publish a libpvm.a (or whatever) FFI with high performance PVM interpretation/recompilation in the same way they are currently publishing compiled binary fuzzer targets while ALSO satisfying clean room requirements, I assume, if these recompiler/intepreter impls aren't publishing their code (or people don't look inside them when they do). All recompiler teams can publish a library without publishing any source anything beyond an API -- something close to pvm.h can work for both C+Rust, and I'd like to see if this can work in late 2025 rather than late 2026 or 2027. Nearly 1.5 years has passed since rules were published. At least for the 15+ enrolled teams who have already built a PVM interpreter, we're now _well_ beyond the _educational value of training these teams_ ... and now to the point where we can want PVM fuzzing and **performance** and **robustness** in PVM libraries instead. I see little point in having PVM fuzzing of non-performant PVM interpreters, except to satisfy the rules. In contrast, if the "C(++)/Rust" + "hybrid" recompiler teams provide PVM library for others, provided that the bug fixes flow to improve the robust production-grade high performant PVM libraries rather than the throwaway low performance PVM interpreters, we win something meaningfully better. Is this actually a debate? Am I missing how important it is to have these throwaway PVM interpreters go through some PVM fuzz process for some reason? You can also distinguish between "unofficial" vs. "official" -- the beloved fuzzing processes are marked "unofficial", and you can still have the "official" process go through everyone's original throwaway PVM interpreter. But if everyone's slow language implementation fuzzing goes 20-100x times faster using a library in the "unofficial" process, we should do that smarter thing, especially if it improves the end goal of having more robust more performant PVM recompilers and thus JAM implementations generally. (edited)
# 2025-09-13 01:12 dave: > I don't think there is any value in these slow PVM interpreters except for the fact that they trained us You're right that there is little direct value in yet another slow PVM interpreter. The value is in the process of creating this interpreter: reading and interpreting the GP, and resolving the inevitable mismatches with other implementations. The more times this is done the more likely it is that we find all the issues in the GP, and the more likely it is that all implementations actually match the GP. There are two reasons I said I would be careful about integrating a third-party PVM at this point: - The PVM interface itself is likely to imply a particular interpretation of the GP. It could arguably be considered code, even if it's just function prototypes and type definitions. - If you're integrating with say PolkaVM, you'd have to be rather careful not to look at the PolkaVM code when debugging and so on. Yes, this probably isn't a concern if you're just using a binary with no debug info. Of course, teams following the non-PVM path will have to integrate with a third-party PVM at some point if they want to atttempt the performance milestones. In my opinion that would best be done after M1/M2.
# 2025-09-13 01:21 dave: FWIW I don't think we intend to make the "unofficial" fuzzing particularly fast. We really do _not_ want teams to be fixing their implementations solely based on fuzzing against PolkaJam. At the end of the day PolkaJam is just another implementation and will have its own bugs and mismatches with the GP, which we certainly don't want copied
# 2025-09-13 05:35 jan: > The PVM interface itself is likely to imply a particular interpretation of the GP. It could arguably be considered code, even if it's just function prototypes and type definitions. For the PolkaVM crate specifically I'd say that looking at the public interface (i.e. most of what docs.rs show as long as you don't click on show source) should be safe to do; there isn't really much JAM-specific about it, and it's just a garden variety VM interface. The initial API was mostly based on what wasmtime has, and then I just introduced a slightly lower level common-sense expansion to that API that allows handling host calls and page faults without having to register callbacks, and that's mostly it. There are some types there which are for dealing with program blobs and such, but this is very minor and is similar to what we ourselves publish as part of the current JAM SDK (and even less I'd argue; PolkaVM exposes an interface to operate on .polkavm blobs, which is not part of the GP, while the JAM SDK includes code for JAM blobs which are part of the GP).
# 2025-09-13 05:51 jan: As far as I'm concerned people are welcome to borrow my API as long as they don't look at the implementation; it doesn't expose anything more than any other general purpose VM would or what a JAM SDK would. I explicitly try to keep it as general-purpose and not JAM-specific as I can (unlike most other PVM implementations that I've seen which are very much geared towards being JAM-only VMs), and (for various reasons) I also have a bunch of stuff that's either experimental or even subtly non-compliant with the GP, so if someone's just blindly copying without understanding the GP they will have a bad time.
# 2025-09-13 06:06 jan: Besides, later down the line we will most certainly need a common PVM API for the M3+ milestones to make PVM performance testing possible and practical. For example, we will definitely need to measure the performance of how fast people's recompilers can generate code separately from how the code executes - checking the recompilation performance is mostly a manner of checking whether it's O(n) and how fast it can go, while execution performance testing needs to verify that the performance is within what the gas cost model assumes, and thus they need to be measured separately to make this in any way reliable, and you can't do this without low level access to the PVM (lower than what just running a service on JAM provides). So as far as I'm concerned having a common PVM API will pretty much be a JAM prize *requirement*.
# 2025-09-13 16:05 oliver.tale-yazdi: Not sure if I follow the reasoning; what would speak against a Socket-based API like the M1 fuzzer? Requiring a binary ABI does restrict the use of non-native languages for code-emission.
# 2025-09-13 16:09 jan: An interface is an interface, and it doesn't make much difference whether it's called directly or through some sort of an indirection layer like a socket. The extra noise due to the RPC will make it more difficult to do the measurements, but probably not impossible.
# 2025-09-14 01:28 sourabhniyogi: Terrific, totally makes sense -- lets make this PVM API a JIP draft like super-soon! Will take stab at it starting from the polkavm API and see if we can aim for what you have in mind
# 2025-09-15 00:17 jam_man: Not sure if I can ask this here. But it seems appropriate. Jay Chrawnna has stated that this new hard cap for DOT will be “enshrined in JAM and can only be changed through a hard fork” Could anyone explain how we enshrine something In JAM. While I understand that JAM is supposed to be a non-upgradable, fixed-parameter protocol that will host upgradable services, including hosting open-gov itself. Is there really no way for open-gov to modify any aspect of the JAM protocol?
# 2025-09-15 00:18 jam_man: From my understanding, JAM doesn’t even host the DOT token. It will need to be a service on JAM.
# 2025-09-15 00:19 xlchen: JAM host the DOT token. It is the only token hosted by JAM chain. All the balance related logic are referring to DOT (the native token) (edited)
# 2025-09-15 00:20 xlchen: Gav said there will be an editorial board for GP, so update of GP will go through that.
# 2025-09-15 00:21 xlchen: As you already said, JAM chain is not designed to be upgradable. So upgrades requires hard fork. Then the rest is just how hard fork upgrade works. i.e. social consensus.
# 2025-09-15 00:25 jam_man: Hm, ya that’s what I assumed. That you could simply force a hard fork with an open-gov proposal. Which does not inherently enshrine it? Has this concept been discussed for JAM. Can forks be forced by proposals, or will it be up to the node operators.
# 2025-09-15 00:27 xlchen: what open gov can do is boot off / slash uncooperative validators (edited)
# 2025-09-15 00:27 xlchen: so in some way, it can be done
# 2025-09-15 00:38 jam_man: I see thank you. And now I see. The Gray paper outlines how the networks Balances (NB) are baked into consensus as 64-bit unsigned integers. So it’s not a service at all. I assumed we would have to bring DOT over as a service. This is actually good to know. Thank you again.
# 2025-09-17 15:20 danicuki: Will M1 submissions begin to be accepted once the fuzzer test software for 0.7.0 is complete?

My guess is we don't have 1.0 ratification until Q4 2025 + Q1 2026 and this ratification, given 0.5 => 0.7 took the first 9 months of 2025 -- is this a good guess?
# 2025-09-17 17:39 danicuki: ☝️
# 2025-09-17 18:55 sourabhniyogi: Lol -- always good to make the judge, jury and executioner happy. But I don't see the reason why we should be in a rush to submit.

# 2025-09-20 14:13 hitchhooker:
# 2025-09-20 14:34 sourabhniyogi: We have an awesomely clear idea about M1 conformance (and increasingly good resolution about what M3/M4 is about, at least for PVM) ... but not M2 -- can you provide guidance on M2 conformance requirements so those of us who are ready \[pretty much all enrolled teams\] can spend our extra hours on that most effectively for the rest of the year? If this can't be defined precisely because it sounds like a promise, perhaps a "soft target" proxy to focus teams works very well: "M2 conformance would be to author blocks and refine DOOM work packages with jamt alongside polkajam + another team in a tiny testnet for N hours". Then the rules could be loosened (without premature ratification of 1.0) in a predictable way while ensuring everyone is focused on the next 2 milestones by having soft targets for both, something like "If you can include in your M(n) report how you met the soft targets of M(n+1) and M(n+2), then ___". This keeps implementers focussed meeting the engineering goals of the M(n) hard target while also attempting the M(n+1) and M(n+2) soft targets and sacrifices nothing on desired conformance goals of the hard target. Does that make sense? (edited)

# 2025-10-02 17:14 clearloop: Hi there, our service sdk jade is now ready to be hacked! for the quickstart of jade 
cargo install jade
jade new my-service
cd my-service
cargo test
for the recent releases: - now jade is using dependencies from spacejam directly - introduced the system interface of SpaceVM (both compiler and interpreter) - I just found that I have written a instruction table for PVM months ago...feel free to check it out for fun - our website is open sourced and updated with more links I have prepared 2 simple issues in jade for new devs in JAM that don't know where to start, which are about - the skill of reading graypaper - understanding how host call works in the services - writing service tests using jade happy hacking! (edited)

# 2025-10-08 20:49 davxy: Hi! Could I ask what is implementation? Also, have you implemented the fuzzer protocol for M1? You can find more info here: https://github.com/davxy/jam-conformance/tree/main/fuzz-proto
# 2025-10-09 06:52 jan: As you may or may not know, I'm working on the new gas cost model for JAM. I'm finally at a point where I will be merging the initial implementation of the new gas cost model into PolkaVM, and updating the GP to include it. So I'm looking for volunteers. The task is simple: commit to implement the new gas cost model in your PVM based on my draft changes to the GP in a timely manner (say, under a week), run some new test vectors I'll prepare (these will be a new kind of test vectors, and won't involve executing any code in your PVM, but only checking the calculated gas costs), and report any feedback you might have. Note that this will not give you any advantage wrt the JAM prize; all of this will be public, and you will not be getting "early access" to anything; the only difference is 1) you give me a commitment to implement this quickly and give feedback, and 2) you'll be implementing something that's not in the GP (yet), so it might be unclear, scuffed, incomplete or still change in a substantial manner. The new gas cost algorithm is complex yet will be a critical part of JAM, so the whole point of this exercise is to get a third-party implementation before it hits the GP, so that we can iron out the issues as fast as possible. Message me if you're interested, and once I have a draft of the GP changes (which, again - will be public; this ain't an early access program) I'll ping you with a link.
# 2025-10-09 11:42 hitchhooker: has jamnp-s been tested to be able to overcome chinese ISPs blocking QUIC traffic? https://labs.apnic.net/presentations/store/2023-03-01-quic-apricot.pdf https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Vc9QiE1CgpE&t=3450s
# 2025-10-09 12:01 dave: It uses QUIC so if that is blocked it's not going to work
# 2025-10-10 13:27 gav: Meh - it’s base layer tech. They won’t block it forever.

# 2025-10-14 12:37 shimonchick: how does one prove their M1 test vectors are passing? Is supplying a binary that runs along with open sourced unit tests work, or perhaps the implementation should generate same files as the test vectors for given case?
# 2025-10-14 13:18 danicuki: How do we represent None or Some(None) in RPC returns? https://github.com/jamixir/JIPs/blob/main/JIP-2.md - is there a standard? JIP-2 doesn't explicitly define.
# 2025-10-14 13:19 danicuki: you provide the binaries to be fuzzed. Take a look here: https://github.com/davxy/jam-conformance/
# 2025-10-14 15:03 igankevich: We recently changed RPC API to use BASE64 encoding for all binary data, including hashes, preimages, segments and other similar types. According to our benchmarks it is much faster to encode a byte array to a BASE64 string and send than to encode it as JSON and send, even for small arrays. This statement is true for both Rust and Javascript-based clients. You can find the relevant JIP PR here: https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/JIPs/pull/9
# 2025-10-14 17:50 aang114: image.jpg
# 2025-10-14 17:50 aang114: Hi, does anyone know if the state component θ is supposed to be ordered by the service index? Because one of our failing fuzzer tests seems to be because θ is not ordered by service index. Thanks (edited)
# 2025-10-14 18:00 jaymansfield: C(16) shows that order matters for θ and dictionaries default to order by key (C.10). I sort them in JavaJAM. (edited)
# 2025-10-14 18:28 aang114: I see. I'll do the same then. Thanks man But now I'm wondering how would we sort it we had 2 elements in θ with the same service index then 🤔?
# 2025-10-14 18:28 aang114: e.g: if we had the elements (2, 0x00) and (2, 0x01)
# 2025-10-15 00:57 ascriv: Then you order based on the second elements’ lexicographic order I believe (edited)
# 2025-10-15 06:57 vinsystems: Is there a possibility of accumulate twice the same service in the same block?
# 2025-10-15 07:21 gav: Yes
# 2025-10-15 07:22 gav: That is indeed the meaning of lexicographic ordering.
# 2025-10-15 07:22 gav: Think dictionary.
# 2025-10-15 07:24 gav: As long as we’re only dealing with tuples of scalar values then there’s a well-defined lexicographic order. (edited)
# 2025-10-15 07:25 gav: And it extends to other things like sequences and sets as long as you’re only comparing like with like (we don’t define how to compare a sequence with a scalar in the GP because it is never needed) (edited)
# 2025-10-15 12:16 dhruv245: Hi, I wanted to check if there are any confirmed dates for the submission of M1 and M2. My team has already completed both modules, so I’d like to know the next steps.
# 2025-10-16 04:34 davxy: The fuzzer for M1 is maturing, and I know W3F is planning to start using it to test targets officially. That said, based on my experiments **there is still NO target I can fuzz continuously for minutes in a row**. Things have improved **a lot** over the past couple of months, but that's not enough yet as targets need to be fuzzed for days. My impression is that longer-running fuzzing will arrive soon, at least for some implementations. My suggestions: - Join the teams listed here so we can quickly review your M1 work. - Keep the discussion public, I will not take private conversations on Telegram or other closed channels.
# 2025-10-16 10:17 prematurata: about jam-np the &quot;path to the start key&quot; should terminate either at a fork node with an all-zeroes hash in the branch that would be taken for the start key, or at a leaf node with a different key This means that in case the key is not found, if the given start key should be in the empty branch, would i just need to return the "parent branch node" or ???
# 2025-10-16 10:58 dave: Yeah you should include the node with the empty branch in the boundary node list in that case

A couple of teams volunteered to implement this before it lands (and their feedback will heavily influence when/how it will land). # 2025-10-21 12:14 sourabhniyogi: What is the plan to get the gas model for the host functions, especially the storage/IO intensive ones (read/write+import/export)?
# 2025-10-21 21:13 jan: Benchmark and measure their cost, then add the costs to the GP. This will not be done at the same time as we'll migrate to the new gas cost model. For now we'll assign them some placeholder costs, and we'll update them at a later date to their proper values (these are just some constant numbers, so they'll be trivial to update in your implementation too) (edited)
# 2025-10-21 13:22 xcrom1: image.png
# 2025-10-21 13:22 xcrom1: Hello everyone, I’ve been trying to clarify how JAM’s computation pipeline fits together visually, here’s my current understanding based on the Graypaper v0.7.2. The diagram outlines the four main phases: Join -> Refine -> Accumulate -> Finalize and includes the roles involved (Guarantors, Assurers, Auditors, Judges), the Toasters, and the consensus layer (Safrole + Grandpa) I’d really appreciate feedback on whether this representation aligns with the model described in the graypaper. Are there any nuances or clarifications you would suggest, for example regarding how the in-core and on-chain processes interact, or where the Assurers fit precisely? Thanks in advance for your insights
# 2025-10-21 13:25 dave: This does not seem very accurate. The word "toaster" doesn't appear in the GP, neither does the word "judge" as a noun
# 2025-10-21 13:28 dave: The "toaster" is just a bunch of machines set up for testing JAM implementations
# 2025-10-21 13:31 xcrom1: Thanks for the feeback, that's helpful, You're right "toaster isn’t in the GP, I used it to represent the execution cores that handle in-core computation. As for “judge”, I took it from the adjudication process described in the later sections (around settlement and finalization), but you’re right that it’s not used as a role noun. I’ll probably adjust the terminology to stay closer to the GP language, appreciate you pointing it out.
# 2025-10-21 13:38 dave: It is inaccurate to say that "a service submits a calculation". A service is something that exists on-chain and defines the refine and accumulate logic, and has some associated state. Services are largely not autonomous and need to be driven by work-packages that are generated by builders. Builders are a totally separate concept to services.
# 2025-10-21 13:43 xcrom1: That makes sense, so the Service defines the logic and state, while Builders actually generate the work packages that drive computation. I’ll update the Join phase accordingly, thanks a lot for clarifying.
# 2025-10-22 03:33 ascriv: Should implementations be maintaining an interpreted version even after they implement the recompiled version?
# 2025-10-22 03:35 jan: It's up to you. It's always useful for debugging to have an interpreter, plus to be able to run on platforms which your recompiler doesn't target. In PolkaVM I will never remove my interpreter.
# 2025-10-22 03:36 jan: For M3+ a recompiler will be absolutely required, however it's very very unlikely that we will actually require an interpreter for anything.
# 2025-10-22 05:07 shimonchick: In the PVM test vectors, i am trying to find the reason most basic programs take 2 GAS and return panic instead of HALT. Is there an implicit instruction added to the end? (edited)
# 2025-10-22 10:15 jan: Yes. Are you implementing your PVM based on the test vectors, or on the GP? Because the GP is quite explicit in what happens here. :P
# 2025-10-22 05:28 clearloop: will this gas update being included in M1 ? I can see it belongs to the v0.7.x milestone in gavofyork/graypaper, and seems after v0.7, v0.8-v0.9 is focus on the rest of the protocol (M2)
# 2025-10-22 10:19 jan: I'm not the one working on the M1 conformance testing nor do I make the rules so take this with a grain of salt, but I'd assume this could depend on how fast we can get the new gas cost model in the GP, and how long it will take for the teams to get their clients to a state where they don't fail in the first 10 minutes of fuzzying. Anyhow, probably only Gav or W3F people can give you an official answer.
# 2025-10-22 07:52 danicuki: > <@xcrom1:matrix.org> Hello everyone, > > I’ve been trying to clarify how JAM’s computation pipeline fits together visually, here’s my current understanding based on the Graypaper v0.7.2. > > The diagram outlines the four main phases: > Join -> Refine -> Accumulate -> Finalize > and includes the roles involved (Guarantors, Assurers, Auditors, Judges), the Toasters, and the consensus layer (Safrole + Grandpa) > > I’d really appreciate feedback on whether this representation aligns with the model described in the graypaper. > Are there any nuances or clarifications you would suggest, for example regarding how the in-core and on-chain processes interact, or where the Assurers fit precisely? > > Thanks in advance for your insights Here is another diagram with some insights: https://x.com/danicuki/status/1897217853482250433?s=46
# 2025-10-22 08:02 xcrom1: It’s a really helpful complement, appreciate you sharing it
# 2025-10-22 08:03 danicuki: This doc describes in detail: https://hackmd.io/@w_7Gu9yjR4q8dsYR89m4OA/BJB1ExR5ye
# 2025-10-22 08:52 danicuki: We’ve seen this week a major AWS failure. We have the opportunity to spread the narrative of decentralized systems. But we know that decentralization doesn’t come for free. The question is: how much more expensive is it to run a computation on JAM compared to running it on an ordinary cloud server? Since every core has 3 validators (3x), and suppose PVM runs at 50-70% native speed (1.5-2x), would it be fair to claim that JAM cloud would cost ~5-7x more than ordinary cloud server? What about storage? 3x? What about memory usage? Also 3x? What about networking? At the end, companies that failed on AWS know that redundancy would prevent failures, but redundancy and resilience comes with higher costs. How feasible is it for companies to spend 3x on cloud infrastructure to avoid improbable downtimes ?
# 2025-10-22 09:02 alice_und_bob: Web2 Clouds and Web3 Clouds go for different properties that they offer. Web2 Clouds can offer latency, scale, and compute that Web3 Clouds cannot offer. OTOH, Web3 Clouds can offer unstoppability, censorship resistance, manipulation resistance etc... So imo the two offerings go hand in hand. That said, yes, one big differentiation of Web3 Clouds could offer superior uptime guarantees for the services they provide But I wouldn't hinge the argument on cost when comparing Web2 to Web3; we could rather make that argument against competing Web3 offerings
# 2025-10-22 12:44 danicuki: I am not looking for cost number to serve as selling argument web2 vs web3. But still it is a number that we all should know. How much are we paying for security and resilience? 3x? 6x? In the end, it is a trade off, and as system architects, we should be aware of it
# 2025-10-22 13:46 danicuki: Screenshot 2025-10-22 at 14.45.41.png
# 2025-10-22 13:52 danicuki: RFCWhat do you think?
# 2025-10-22 13:52 gav: It's not the actual speed of PVM which matters sadly. It's the gas model. And the gas model limits compute throughput to be ~10x-100x less than native/cloud. Furthermore JAM provides materially less interaction (disk I/O, network and GPU) than would be commonly expected of a cloud service. JAM cannot host typical software or languages in quite the same way (though CoreVM does lift this limit somewhat) but certainly Web3 services need to be designed from the ground up to use Web3 infrastructure and agentic, economically-sound design. (edited)
# 2025-10-22 13:54 gav: Trying to pretend that JAM is a drop-in replacement for AWS would be almost as ill-informed and counter-productive as trying to pretend the same of Ethereum. It really makes very little sense to try to compare Web2 systems quantitatively to Web3. It's a bit like trying to state the difference between feudalism and Athenian democracy by comparing average calorific intake of their populations (edited)
# 2025-10-22 13:56 gav: Both Polkadot and JAM deliver resilience together with scale (which can also be stated as low-cost). But by splitting everything apart into relatively isolated "L2" parachains, Polkadot compromises on coherence. JAM's Refine-Accumulate model is much more coherent and allows state components of the overall system to interact much more fluidly. (edited)
# 2025-10-22 13:58 gav: Until there's high-utility/popularity then being scalable/low-cost can be something of a curse.
# 2025-10-22 14:02 danicuki: Could we say that JAM provides same resilience and a slightly better cost than Polkadot?
# 2025-10-22 14:08 gav: Yes it probably has a somewhat better cost in terms of storage, but that's _really_ missing the point. (edited)
# 2025-10-22 14:10 gav: With the present gas model, JAM/PVM and Polkadot/Wasm are probably very comparable in terms of compute throughput. This is because Polkadot makes very particular assumptions about the circumstances in which the Wasm will be executed. It doesn't do metering. It assumes cores are for parachains and parachains are trust-worthy.
# 2025-10-22 14:10 gav: JAM has a bigger DA than Polkadot right now, but it wouldn't be too difficult to lift that limit either.
# 2025-10-22 14:11 gav: JAM has more validators than Polkadot, but as we know, validator counts can change.
# 2025-10-22 14:12 gav: As I've previously said, JAM's main advantage is to bring coherence and not dramatically bigger numbers.
# 2025-10-22 14:13 gav: I realise that an audience focussed on quantitative information such as price is probably most comfortable looking at performance numbers since they're most familiar.
# 2025-10-22 14:14 gav: However, if you look at JAM that way you'll miss most of the important stuff.
# 2025-10-22 14:16 gav: Coherence - the ability for two different bits of the overarching system to easily and usefully interact - underpins almost everything that Ethereum achieved. Generality - the ability to formulate Turing-complete pieces of logic to be executed on demand - underpins the rest. (edited)
# 2025-10-22 14:16 gav: JAM delivers on both of these while retaining Polkadot's scale (low-cost) and resilience.
# 2025-10-22 14:16 gav: To get all four things at once is a big deal.
# 2025-10-22 14:21 gav: They're delivered by PVM (and particularly the ability to have arbitrary numbers of "hypervisor-like" inner PVMs) and the overall reformulation of the compute model into Refine+Accumulate and a shared DA, enabling a level of coherency not too far from that of a typical "computer". (edited)
# 2025-10-22 14:24 vinsystems: Would be feasible to run a Linux container (LXC) on top of CoreVM? (edited)
# 2025-10-22 14:42 gav: Someone will need to try. There's no obvious reason why not that I can think of. (edited)
# 2025-10-22 14:43 gav: However, just because you have a basic Linux environment doesn't change the fact that to deliver a Web3 service you need to architect in the agentic spirit.
# 2025-10-22 14:44 gav: All it does is open up some logic and languages which might otherwise have been hard to utilise.
# 2025-10-22 14:44 gav: You won't get a random number generator. You won't get internet access. You won't be able to "serve web pages" in any sensible reading of the phrase. You won't be able to make RPC calls. You won't be able to offer real-time game coordination. (edited)
# 2025-10-22 14:46 gav: This is what I mean when Web2 and Web3 are just not comparable quantitatively.
# 2025-10-22 14:48 gav: Web2 is wild-west. Cowboy. No guarantees that anything will work as expected. Arbiters everywhere.
# 2025-10-22 14:49 gav: Web3 is trustlessness. Certain. Clockwork. Credible rational arguments about why the service will work as expected.
# 2025-10-22 14:50 gav: However it's not only slower/more costly, but also - crucially - build with different expectations and constraints. One typical constraint of Web3 is determinism. And this precludes all sorts of stuff which can be done under the more laissez-faire Web2 frameworks (multi-threading, networking, GPUs, RNGs, ...)
# 2025-10-22 14:52 gav: We'll eventually make Web3 systems more and more efficient and closer and closer to basic Web2 performance indicators (RAM, compute, persistent data I/O). JAM's a fairly substantial milestone there. But we're not likely to close much of the gap with regard to the architecture and design philosophy needed for architecting resilient (Web3) services. A bit of extra CPU speed makes little difference when we wonder about getting a properly random die roll or the ability to query a JSON-RPC service on demand. (edited)
# 2025-10-22 14:54 gav: Indeed, when we come to architecting things like shared-deck card games (Exploding Kittens?) you might be surprised at the level of technology involved when you remove the third-party.
# 2025-10-22 14:55 gav: Some of these problems make the world of finance look comparatively trivial.
# 2025-10-22 15:13 ascriv: R.e. randomness primitive: could we get this by aggregating VRFs from validators (threshold combination)?
# 2025-10-22 15:16 ascriv: I guess the same entropy could then be reused globally for all “public draw” events on all games on jam
# 2025-10-22 17:26 dave: FYI there is a reasonably stable spec for the JAM node telemetry interface here: https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/JIPs/pull/8. As with the SNP spec, we won't change things at this point without good reason! We are currently developing a front-end for this which will collate telemetry events from connected nodes and display them in interesting and hopefully useful ways :). We will likely require nodes to implement this before we will allow them to run on the toaster.
# 2025-10-22 17:40 gav: The crypto to give a threshold deterministic random value required a trusted set up last time I checked. Alistair?
# 2025-10-22 17:52 alistair: Not a trusted setup, a distributed key generation protocol. Which is as simple as them all generating something and then aggregating these.
# 2025-10-23 04:35 jan: It's turing complete, so technically you can run anything. It really depends on what exactly you mean by "Linux container". Is it unmodified Linux AMD64 executables? It's going to be painfully slow because you'll be running them under an interpreter. Is it a bunch of programs recompiled to PVM plus a Linux syscall emulation layer? Feasible, would run relatively fast, but would need work to make it happen.
# 2025-10-23 08:03 vinsystems: I mean taking the LXC source code and porting/adapting it to run on CoreVM. I don't intend to execute unmodified AMD64 binaries directly, but rather to recompile LXC and its dependencies, leveraging the Linux syscall emulation that has been implemented in CoreVM. I know it would require modifications to CoreVM and that not all LXC features would be available, but the goal would be to achieve at least a basic virtualized Linux user space: an isolated environment where you can start a rootfs and run multiple processes.
# 2025-10-24 14:04 dakkk: Why don't you create a PR on graypaper repo?
# 2025-10-24 20:47 jaymansfield: > <@dave:parity.io> FYI there is a reasonably stable spec for the JAM node telemetry interface here: https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/JIPs/pull/8. As with the SNP spec, we won't change things at this point without good reason! We are currently developing a front-end for this which will collate telemetry events from connected nodes and display them in interesting and hopefully useful ways :). We will likely require nodes to implement this before we will allow them to run on the toaster. Is there a target date of when you expect the frontend to be available? Any chance implementers could get access to dev versions of it so we can start to validate our telemetry implementations (even if it doesn’t support full event coverage yet)?
# 2025-10-26 21:54 celadari: Hi, I have a doubt regarding a specific test vector different-core-same-guarantors https://github.com/davxy/jam-test-vectors/blob/master/stf/reports/tiny/different\_core\_same\_guarantors-1.json\` we have two work reports with same lookup_anchor and different lookup_anchor_slot: 
"context": {
                        ....
                        "lookup_anchor": "0x16bda47e5a68daf53c39ddee8af4ecaced7e87f3f0ac9da5a6f4f9e41350d319",
                        "lookup_anchor_slot": 6,
                    },
and 
"context": {
                        ...
                        "lookup_anchor": "0x16bda47e5a68daf53c39ddee8af4ecaced7e87f3f0ac9da5a6f4f9e41350d319",
                        "lookup_anchor_slot": 10,
                    },
according to https://graypaper.fluffylabs.dev/#/1c979cb/15f00215f902?v=0.7.1 that would require us to have stored two headers with the same hash but different time slot => not possible (edited)
# 2025-10-27 17:08 igankevich: This would require implementing all system calls that LXC uses, in particular process creation and networking. This would take some time, but otherwise I don't see much of a problem to do that. The only remaining question is "Why?" 😃 LXC is basically a chroot with namespace-based isolation for processes, network, root file system etc. PolkaVM gives much higher degree of isolation and also full reproducibility. If your goal is to protect the program and the outside world from each other, you can just run it on CoreVM without LXC.
# 2025-10-27 19:41 dave: Tonight's PolkaJam release (https://github.com/paritytech/polkajam-releases) should include a jam-telemetry-dumper binary which you can use for debugging. It simply accepts connections from nodes and dumps any received events straight to stdout without any processing. The polkajam and polkajam-testnet binaries in the release should support the --telemetry flag which you can point at this. I believe erin intends to release a more interesting CLI frontend later this week. The web frontend should be usable by the end of the year, although it likely won't be feature-complete.
# 2025-10-27 19:56 xlchen: could the telemetry frontend to be public so people can contribute?
# 2025-10-27 19:57 dave: It's in a separate repo to PolkaJam so we should be able to make it public yeah
# 2025-10-28 08:14 vinsystems: Thanks for the feedback, Ivan! You're right that implementing the necessary syscalls (like those for process creation and networking) would take some effort, but it's good to hear it's feasible in principle. The basic Linux user space setup I mentioned is really just a first step to validate the concept and ensure the syscall emulation layer holds up under something like LXC's isolation features. But the final goal is enabling a more complete Linux environment (including full networking support). That way, we could provide a seamless migration path for existing web2 services to web3, with minimal changes required. Imagine porting over running applications or services directly into JAM without major rewrites (leveraging LXC-like containers to bridge the gap). Do you think that's a compelling use case, or are there other hurdles I'm missing? (edited)
# 2025-10-28 09:26 igankevich: > Imagine porting over running applications or services directly into JAM without major rewrites (leveraging LXC-like containers to bridge the gap). Do you think that's a compelling use case, or are there other hurdles I'm missing? It would be awesome to port applications of course 😃 Arguably the most valuable offer of application container platforms is their hubs. Hence, I think, the most straightforward approach to port an application would be to pull Docker/LXC/whatever image from a hub, convert it to CoreVM FS image and run the entry point inside CoreVM. This is how Singularity entered the scene as a new application container platform back in the days: you just type singularity shell docker://ubuntu:latest and it "steals" Ubuntu image from the Docker hub, converts it to its own format, and launches the shell. It should be possible (and not that difficult!) to write a similar CLI tool for CoreVM. Please also keep in mind that there is no Internet access inside CoreVM, so most Docker commands (e.g. docker pull, lxc create) inside CoreVM will not work. This kinda defeats the purpose of porting application container platforms to CoreVM, isn't it? (It might not work outside either because CoreVM needs riscv64 architecture and most images are built for different architectures.) My point is that running LXC/Docker inside CoreVM is not that transparent due to a lack of access to hubs. A more user-friendly way of running "old" containerized applications on CoreVM would be to do that directly via a converter tool that I mentioned above. Eventually it would make sense to create an on-chain hub with riscv64 images stored in e.g. IPFS or something to not depend on web2 hubs.
# 2025-10-28 11:04 gav: Bernar | Vinwolf^^^ see this
# 2025-10-28 11:05 gav: Just dropping nginx or Postgres into a Linux container hosted in CoreVM isn’t going to achieve anything useful. At least not directly. (edited)
# 2025-10-28 11:10 gav: The latency is high (multiples of 6 seconds for Polkadot, maybe multiples of single seconds for Kusama if things go well). There is no networking.
# 2025-10-28 11:10 gav: This is a Web3 platform for hosting appropriately architected Web3 software. (edited)
# 2025-10-28 11:11 gav: The “endpoint” for Web3 isn’t “Web2 but on many (public) nodes”. (edited)
# 2025-10-28 11:12 gav: (Not is it on just “many nodes” - that’s distributed computing and it’s what Google already does in its data centres.) (edited)
# 2025-10-28 11:16 gav: Bitcoin isn’t “legacy banking software but extended on to many nodes”.
# 2025-10-28 11:16 gav: Rather it is its own protocol, utilising game theoretic and cryptographic mechanisms to deliver a certain service a bit like the services that banks provide.
# 2025-10-28 11:17 gav: So it will be with other vestiges of Web3.
# 2025-10-28 11:20 gav: The difference between Web3 stuff and Web2 is the trust architecture. And while JAM provides some really good improvements in terms of coherence, performance and compute environment, that doesn’t alter the need to consider and design the services which run on it from the ground up.
# 2025-10-28 11:21 gav: It just means that development, scaling and integration will be much easier to achieve together without throwing decentralisation and resilience to the wind.
# 2025-10-28 11:22 gav: It could nevertheless be fun to get LXC working in CoreVM, but probably more as a 💪 demo than anything really that useful.
# 2025-10-28 11:27 alice_und_bob: what I typically find very helpful when considering ideas like these in systems design is to think in terms of tradeoffs. What am I gaining and what am I giving? On the most basic level in system properties Typical Web2 properties are: large amounts of storage, compute, low latency... Typical Web3 properties are: censorship resistance, verifiability + privacy if you add ZK So when considering an idea like "nginx on JAM", you can ask: what do I get and what do I give? You might get a time saver on not having to reimplement the stack and you gain verifiability, but what is that good for for a simple web server? And what you give is performance and more money. So the tradeoffs don't yield a very attractive result in this case (edited)
# 2025-10-28 11:29 alice_und_bob: but the idea of tradeoff implies is that you typically can't have all the positives at once. usually something has to give so that you gain something else
# 2025-10-28 11:33 alice_und_bob: for distributed ledgers one shortcut question I often go to is: what are truths that everyone / a lot of people want to agree on? if the application in question contains truths / calculations that a lot of people want to agree on, it makes sense to put it on-chain. the serving of files from a server to a single user is not something that everyone has a strong need to verify/agree on
# 2025-10-29 19:09 erin: Hello everyone, I've released a telemetry server which is compatible with JIP-3 for JAM nodes. You can find the release binaries here This consists of two parts, the backend (telemetry server) which stores emitted events from connected nodes in postgres. The recommended way to run this is in docker, but you can find a variety of helper scripts in the repo to modify to your environment as needed. The other part is the cli interface, which is TUI, called tart-dash. If anyone has any problems, suggestions, or otherwise, please ping me! (edited)
# 2025-10-29 19:12 erin: Screenshot 2025-10-29 at 19.12.00.png
# 2025-10-29 19:13 erin: This will be improved upon in the coming days/weeks both according to the spec and your feedback if you have any. :) A more fully-featured web UI is also in active development.
# 2025-10-30 10:35 erin: ^ I've released a patch version this morning which added some previously missing event types in the tart-dash.
# 2025-10-31 16:40 dave: FYI I've opened a PR to fix up JIP-2 (which defines the node RPC interface) to reflect the reality of what Parity's JAM tools and PolkaJam currently implement, see https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/JIPs/pull/11. The PR adds a number of new methods which are necessary to run the CoreVM builder, in particular methods for monitoring the status of a work-package, for fetching segments from DA, and for monitoring the sync status of the node.
# 2025-11-02 03:16 jan: I'm happy to announce that we've had the first successful independent replication (which passes all of my test vectors) of the new gas cost model based on my GP draft! I would also like to thank shwchg and tomusdrw in particular, as their feedback was instrumental in getting the draft to this state. Thanks! Ideally I'm aiming to get the new gas cost model into the GP proper sometime this month. There's still a lot of work needed (speccing out the block-based gas charging, some hostcall tweaks, etc.), but the hardest part is now done (getting the gas cost model itself specced) and with the way things are going there is a significant possibility that this new gas cost model could become part of the M1 milestone (it will definitely be part of M2) depending on how fast I can get it into GP and how much more time it will take for the W3F to get ready to accept submissions. So I just wanted to communicate this so that there are no surprises - if you have the free time and are twiddling your thumbs waiting for the M1 milestone testing to open it might be a good idea to start implementing the new gas cost model already, as at this point the algorithm is very unlikely to change.
# 2025-11-03 12:45 shimonchick: ^ can somebody help clarify the format here? thanks 🙏
# 2025-11-07 13:00 clearloop: there is metadata perfixed in the standard format
# 2025-11-07 11:00 shimonchick: Are signatures in https://github.com/davxy/jam-test-vectors/tree/master/traces/fallback generated based on the reference bandersnatch vrf implementation here: https://github.com/davxy/ark-vrf/blob/main/src/ietf.rs ?
# 2025-11-07 19:28 sourabhniyogi: We are coding up the new JAM-NP additions CE 147+148 (+ what we can infer from the GRANDPA) alongside the Telemetry wiring, eager to test out TART this month, should be exciting! Some questions: 1. Happily, the "event ID" parts all made sense and fell into place quite nicely. For Event ID u64, the JIP-3 approach to Telemetry events is always intra-node -- that is, everyone's Event IDs are generated locally and are never shared except with the telemetry server ... but never \*inter-\*node, so far as I can tell. This intra-node-only approach is perfect for logging/visualizing the behavior of individual nodes, but it doesn't assist in visualizing the behavior across nodes (unless TART does a lot of amazing guesswork to stitch all the different nodes' eventIDs together!). The EventID could have optional or required bytes beyond the present u64, to model the key already present in JAM-NP - epoch (CE131/132): for ticketing (events 80-84) - work package hash (CE133/134/135): for refining/auditing by builder/guarantor/auditor (90-113) - erasureRoot (CE137/138/139/140/147): for assuring/DA (events 120-153) - segmentsRoot (CE148): for assuring/DA (events 160-178) - preimagehash (CE142/143): for preimages (events 190-199) - peerID (UP0/..): for peering (events 20-28, 60-61) - header hash (UP0/CE128/141): for authoring/importing/assuring (events 40-48, 62-68, 11+12?) Having an additional key (already present in JAM-NP) to support inter-node event analysis could eliminate TART guesswork and map onto other distributed telemetry systems. What do you think? 2. For CE 148: Segment request -- is the [Segment] [Import-Proof] suppose to mean (a) send the segment for the first index, then the import proof for the first segment, then the segment for the second index, then the import proof for the second segment, etc. OR (b) send all the segments back to back, then all the import proofs back to back for the same segment in the same order Also, for the import proof, these are just CDT justifications for the segment alone, yes? 3. For Telemetry 161: Segments-root mapped -- In 160, we can map a requested hash (which can be a Work package hash OR Segments-Root) with the information in the Segment Root Lookup. But for 161 we need to map Segments-Root to Erasure-Root with a disk lookup... just to provide a telemetry signal, which seems wrong. Is this a concern? Perhaps you meant Work Package Hash instead of Erasure-Root? (edited)
# 2025-11-08 14:53 danicuki: Screenshot 2025-11-07 at 18.49.59.png
# 2025-11-08 14:53 danicuki: Jamixir is on TART 😃
# 2025-11-08 14:56 danicuki: As far as I understood, TART always stores pair (node_id, event_id) for events, so, events are tied to nodes also. If all nodes connect to the same Telemetry Server, theoretically telemetry has all data it needs to measure cross-nodes. Does this make sense?
# 2025-11-09 20:01 dave: > <@sourabhniyogi:matrix.org> We are coding up the new JAM-NP additions CE 147+148 (+ what we can infer from the GRANDPA) alongside the Telemetry wiring, eager to test out TART this month, should be exciting! Some questions: > > 1. Happily, the "event ID" parts all made sense and fell into place quite nicely. For Event ID u64, the JIP-3 approach to Telemetry events is always intra-node -- that is, everyone's Event IDs are generated locally and are never shared except with the telemetry server ... but never \*inter-\*node, so far as I can tell. This intra-node-only approach is perfect for logging/visualizing the behavior of individual nodes, but it doesn't assist in visualizing the behavior across nodes (unless TART does a lot of amazing guesswork to stitch all the different nodes' eventIDs together!). The EventID could have optional or required bytes beyond the present u64, to model the key already present in JAM-NP > > - epoch (CE131/132): for ticketing (events 80-84) > - work package hash (CE133/134/135): for refining/auditing by builder/guarantor/auditor (90-113) > - erasureRoot (CE137/138/139/140/147): for assuring/DA (events 120-153) > - segmentsRoot (CE148): for assuring/DA (events 160-178) > - preimagehash (CE142/143): for preimages (events 190-199) > - peerID (UP0/..): for peering (events 20-28, 60-61) > - header hash (UP0/CE128/141): for authoring/importing/assuring (events 40-48, 62-68, 11+12?) > Having an additional key (already present in JAM-NP) to support inter-node event analysis could eliminate TART guesswork and map onto other distributed telemetry systems. What do you think? > > 2. For CE 148: Segment request -- is the [Segment] [Import-Proof] suppose to mean > (a) send the segment for the first index, then the import proof for the first segment, then the segment for the second index, then the import proof for the second segment, etc. OR > (b) send all the segments back to back, then all the import proofs back to back for the same segment in the same order > > Also, for the import proof, these are just CDT justifications for the segment alone, yes? > > 3. For Telemetry 161: Segments-root mapped -- In 160, we can map a requested hash (which can be a Work package hash OR Segments-Root) with the information in the Segment Root Lookup. But for 161 we need to map Segments-Root to Erasure-Root with a disk lookup... just to provide a telemetry signal, which seems wrong. Is this a concern? Perhaps you meant Work Package Hash instead of Erasure-Root? Re 1, yes, event IDs are only for intra-node event linking. For inter-node event linking I expect TART to use things like work-package hash, header hash, peer ID, and so on, as you suggest. These things are provided as soon as they are known, eg the work-package hash is provided in 94: Work-package received. There might be specific instances where I've forgotten to include this stuff, but in general I do not understand what your concern is... perhaps you could elaborate? If the concern is that TART might miss say the 94 event and then not know the work-package hash for a submission from a builder, then yes, that can happen... it hopefully shouldn't happen often though! Re 2, I do not believe this is ambiguous? The answer is (b). > Also, for the import proof, these are just CDT justifications for the segment alone, yes? Yes, I'll clarify this. They're the same as the import proofs that go in work-package bundles. Re 3 if you don't perform this mapping then don't emit an event -- the event description says "Emitted when a segments-root is mapped to an erasure-root for the purpose of segment recovery". For direct recovery from a previous guarantor you do not need to do this mapping, but for sharded recovery you do -- segment shards are requested by erasure root. The purpose of this event is to allow TART to link things together.
# 2025-11-09 20:06 sourabhniyogi: For (1) that is the concern -- having to do heuristic inference. Being able to cover both TART (easy!) and cross-node spans with Jaeger is what I want. For (2), got it, thank you for clarifying! For (3), ok, thank you, now its clear!
# 2025-11-09 21:42 dave: > <@dave:parity.io> Re 1, yes, event IDs are only for intra-node event linking. For inter-node event linking I expect TART to use things like work-package hash, header hash, peer ID, and so on, as you suggest. These things are provided as soon as they are known, eg the work-package hash is provided in 94: Work-package received. There might be specific instances where I've forgotten to include this stuff, but in general I do not understand what your concern is... perhaps you could elaborate? If the concern is that TART might miss say the 94 event and then not know the work-package hash for a submission from a builder, then yes, that can happen... it hopefully shouldn't happen often though! > Re 2, I do not believe this is ambiguous? The answer is (b). > > Also, for the import proof, these are just CDT justifications for the segment alone, yes? > Yes, I'll clarify this. They're the same as the import proofs that go in work-package bundles. > Re 3 if you don't perform this mapping then don't emit an event -- the event description says "Emitted when a segments-root is mapped to an erasure-root for the purpose of segment recovery". For direct recovery from a previous guarantor you do not need to do this mapping, but for sharded recovery you do -- segment shards are requested by erasure root. The purpose of this event is to allow TART to link things together. What do you mean by "cross-node spans with Jaeger"? JIP-3 is specifically for TART. If it's useful for other things as well that's great of course...
# 2025-11-10 19:42 sourabhniyogi: It doesn't matter, since you're rolling your own here, but here is a reference if you're curious to compare the interface https://opentelemetry.io/docs/languages/rust/getting-started/
# 2025-11-09 22:35 oliver.tale-yazdi: Just wanted to drop this here; a minimal code playground for services in C: https://playground.jamcha.in/ using the JamBrains Service SDK. Only the accumulate entry point is currently available. You can check out the PBA example to see the storage API and the accumulation stats in the UI. The Playground server code is private since it is in a monorepo with our JAM client, but the service SDK and examples are public here: https://github.com/JamBrains/service-sdk
# 2025-11-09 22:35 oliver.tale-yazdi: I also got an embedded Python interpreter to run in a JAM service, but it is a bit experimental

# 2025-11-14 18:56 danicuki: I have a doubt about https://github.com/polkadot-fellows/JIPs/blob/main/JIP-4.md: What is the purpose of bootnodes? Genesis state already contains a list of current (and next) validators. Shouldn't this be enough to know where to connect?
# 2025-11-14 19:06 dave: After the chain has been running for a while genesis validators are unlikely to still be running
# 2025-11-14 19:07 dave: IDK if this bootnodes list in the chainspec will be the long-term solution to this, possibly bootnodes will be published somewhere else (eg IPFS)
# 2025-11-14 22:08 danicuki: > <@dave:parity.io> After the chain has been running for a while genesis validators are unlikely to still be running Sure, but the validator list is updated on every epoch and nodes should renew their connections to eventual new validators on the list. I still don’t understand the need for an “external” source of information about nodes.
# 2025-11-14 22:09 dave: You need some entry point to the network?
# 2025-11-15 02:39 jaymansfield: It's more about new nodes joining the network. A new node would only have the genesis information to start. If the genesis validators were no longer online, they could not start requesting blocks to sync as they wouldn't know the current validators (yet).

# 2025-11-21 04:33 shwchg: Hi I have some question about the grandpa and jam-np pr#6 1. Is the authority set the same as the validator set? 2. Regarding CE151, what is the definition of a slot here? 3. Regarding CE153, how do you determine that “the message size is too big”? Also, could you provide a more detailed explanation on how to use this CE?
# 2025-11-21 10:39 matt_halpin: 1. Yes. I'll change those to validator set for consistency.
# 2025-11-21 10:40 matt_halpin: 2. This is slot as defined in the GP (section 4.8)
# 2025-11-21 10:42 matt_halpin: 3. This is really a networking/performance trade off and could be implementation specific. Will see if we need it to be explicitly specified.
# 2025-11-21 10:44 matt_halpin: wrt CE153 there is more of an explanation on using warp sync fragments to sync finality in the Grandpa section above. Let me know if you need any other information.
# 2025-11-21 11:04 shwchg: thanks! follow up question 1. if we are using the validator set. we can get rid of the authority id and change the ed25519pub in the Signed Message... to validator index? 2. so the slot is the node's latest state? what's the usage for that slot
# 2025-11-21 13:28 matt_halpin: 1. tbh Signed Message doesn't really need the public key at all as it's the same as the peer key that was used in the connection. I'll look at removing it.
# 2025-11-21 13:30 matt_halpin: 2. This is to broadcast the latest slot that a validator is voting on. This is so that other validators can know if they're behind others. If all validators are operating normally they should all be voting on the same slot.
# 2025-11-23 08:59 shwchg: Matthew Halpin: So I need to reset the round and change the validator set right after I apply/audit the block from new epoch?
# 2025-11-24 15:03 matt_halpin: You change validator set (and reset round number to 0) after finalizing a set change block. In normal operation the first block of an epoch will be a set change block.
# 2025-11-24 16:31 sourabhniyogi: For CE153 'Warp sync fragments', with Grandpa Justification = Round Number ++ Set Id ++ Commit ++ Votes Ancestries and Votes Ancestries = len++[Header], all responders have to store every Commit = Header Hash ++ Slot ++ len++[Signed Precommit] votes for every validator set since the genesis set to respond. Check? How is the light node receiver supposed to verify Signed Precommit vote unless there is a way to fetch and validate the validators pub keys for each set (from the previous set change). I believe the Ed25519 Public exists in Signed Precommit to not need to fetch any old state. However, I think there has to be a BMT proof for the entire validator set against the Header's StateRoot as well, or instead of this -- otherwise a node could lie to the light client? Then the last BMT proof the light client would verify would be the current/upcoming validator set doing votes in the current epoch/round. We need proofs against JAM State root within headers basically. Actually, I was hoping for a super tight connection between Sec 18 (with a very compact aggregate BLS Signature) and Sec 19 Grandpa to be part of CE153. Because, at the end of the day, the light client has the same problem as what "third party" systems have (what Sec 18 is supposed to solve with BLS aggregate signatures) in this warp sync process. We should want the majority of the light sync process to consist of verifying Validator set's aggregate BLS signatures and verifying the BLS pub keys against the state root finalized at each epoch. However, the problem is the BLS signatures are about hashes of MMR content and the Grandpa votes are about header hashes, and it may be essential to bring these into alignment? Could we have a different CE153 design based off aggregate BLS signatures? (edited)
# 2025-11-25 10:00 matt_halpin: Responders need to store justifications for all set change blocks since genesis. There is a warp sync fragment (header and justification) for every set change block. Being set change blocks the headers include epoch markers, which include Ed25519 public keys for all the new validators, as described in GP section 6.6. These are the validator keys needed for verifying the justification of the next set change block. Does that make sense or have I missed something?
# 2025-11-25 20:09 sourabhniyogi: Makes enough sense to execute on
# 2025-11-29 03:59 sourabhniyogi: Matthew Halpin: Where are you getting the "stakes" of the validators from? I believe the end game is to get it from AssetHub staking module but in the meantime we need some kind of JAM State or JAM DA plan instead of "oh, they are all the same value" (which works as a stub but not much more). Is getting from JAM DA even a possibility or should we use a place in JAM State to hold stakes
# 2025-11-29 11:33 dave: Staking is not part of JAM really, it will be handled by a service. JAM nodes don't need to know about stakes, they just get told the validator sets by this service using the designate-validators host call. Some channel is needed back to this service to get misbehaving validators slashed of course, I don't know exactly how that will work. Guarantor/auditor misbehaviour is recorded on chain already by the disputes stuff. I don't think there is anything to record eg GRANDPA or Safrole equivocations, not sure what exactly is needed there but I would guess something...
# 2025-11-29 11:44 bkchr: For safrole it is basically the equivocating headers and a proof that the validator was part of the active set in the slashable period
# 2025-11-21 07:49 ascriv: I’m trying to understand the long-term economics of JAM. From what I’ve gathered, there’s an intention over the medium-long term to move toward a Polkadot-native stablecoin that would be used both for validator compensation and for paying for JAM execution. If that’s correct, I’m wondering how DOT’s long-term intrinsic value is expected to be maintained. In particular: if the stablecoin is backed uniquely by DOT, does DOT have additional independent utility in the JAM system that gives it non-circular intrinsic value? I’d really appreciate clarification on how the economic separation works between the reserve asset (DOT), the operational currency (the stablecoin), and the JAM execution markets. (edited)

# 2025-11-21 08:14 xlchen: dot is the only token that can be used to pay for storage deposits on jam chain

Since there is no way to request these again, does it then need to then wait for grandpa votes?
# 2025-11-21 15:37 dave: I believe you should just treat it like any other missed judgment
# 2025-11-21 17:29 p.odowd:
# 2025-11-24 02:52 hitchhooker: Basti.await: you mention last developer call need for fast proofs for jam light clients. ligerito could be good fit. https://crates.io/crates/ligerito ~1.5s proving for 64mb blocks 
[I] alice@atomman ~ $ ligerito generate --size 24 | ligerito prove --size 24 | ligerito verify --size 24
Generating 2^24 = 16777216 elements with pattern 'random'
prove: 2^24 GF(2^32), sha256 [release SIMD]
result: 1543.41ms, 1.09e7 elem/s, 246771 bytes
verify: 2^24 GF(2^32), 246771 bytes, sha256 transcript
Verifier: Got initial challenges: [BinaryElem32(BinaryPoly32(4128906081)), BinaryElem32(BinaryPoly32(4080384293)), BinaryElem32(BinaryPoly32(2606407059)), BinaryElem32(BinaryPoly32(3200350211)), BinaryElem32(BinaryPoly32(141099347)), BinaryElem32(BinaryPoly32(3708897727))]
result: VALID 249.40ms
VALID
# 2025-11-24 08:21 bkchr: Yeah I'm not an expert in this topic :D Probably jeff is the better person to talk to about this. But as this is your library and if you may get some time, seeing a real working example of proving grandpa era changes would be nice
# 2025-11-24 19:52 sourabhniyogi: Is it a silly or great idea to have fast proof generation done within refine so we don't need off-refine proving?
# 2025-11-24 20:06 bkchr: Why do proof generation inside of refine? Sounds too costly to me.
# 2025-11-24 20:08 sourabhniyogi: We get 5B gas in refine. With 300ms-600ms proving time, and with PVM gas tracking time accurately @ 1B gas/sec (check?), 300ms-600ms is not costly because, at least with Polkadot's CoreTime model, neither the core time buyer nor WP builder pay for gas -- instead, the core time buyer pays for CoreTime, in a "all you can eat this month" type way, and the builder submits refine able WPs to a core. Right? (edited)
# 2025-11-24 21:29 bkchr: Not sure I understand you?
# 2025-11-24 21:30 bkchr: What you mean by all you can eat? You still need to pay for the all you can eat
# 2025-11-24 21:32 sourabhniyogi: Yes, via CoreTime auctions, not by paying for gas. Once you pay for your coretime, you don't care if your refines cost 4.4B gas or 5B. So you can afford to throw a 600ms proof into your refine.
# 2025-11-24 21:33 bkchr: This assumes that core time is dirt cheap?
# 2025-11-24 21:34 bkchr: I still don't get why you want to build a proof on chain, when you can just build if off chain?
# 2025-11-24 21:35 sourabhniyogi: Whatever it costs, it costs that. The point is that once you pay for that, it doesn't cost extra to do it within refine. So "sounds too costly" doesn't make sense.
# 2025-11-24 21:37 bkchr: Why do you want to do this in refine? What is the advantage of this?
# 2025-11-24 21:42 sourabhniyogi: Fast proofs for service-aware jam light clients that doesn't require additional off-chain infrastructure, or additional off-chain costs. Simpler = better =)
# 2025-11-24 21:45 bkchr: But someone will need to build the refine operation
# 2025-11-24 21:45 bkchr: Aka they will need to run it before once
# 2025-11-24 21:45 bkchr: Aka you need off-chain architecture any way
# 2025-11-24 23:26 sourabhniyogi: Yes, the service builder => guarantor => auditor all do the same refine operation with the service builder being the first actor to do the refine, then guarantors then auditors, with a dozen or so actors. Many people currently call this refine process "off-chain architecture" to help them fit into their blockchain-centric view of the world. I think its useful to get away from this "off-chain architecture" because JAM organizes refine "off-chain architecture" as a key solution to the 'sharding problem'. It will take people some time to stop considering the refine process mere "off-chain architecture" and one that provides massive DA and even light client proof generation if its "fast". If I can generate a compact proof for light clients for a JAM Service within refine cheaply ("cheaply" for me is < 10% of available refine gas of 5B right now) without even more "off-chain architecture" than what JAMs "off-chain" architecture already provides, why wouldn't I include this into refine?
# 2025-11-25 05:53 bkchr: Because it should be actually much cheaper to not do it in refine. And you probably don't need to have consensus around building a proof (which jam will provide you when you do it in refine)
# 2025-11-25 13:54 sourabhniyogi: I can tell you've made up your mind about this. Ok, I'm sold!
# 2025-11-24 21:49 emielsebastiaan: I have a question regarding Rule 13 of the JAM Prize. Rule 13 states: "Following the accepted completion of each milestone, teams may nominate one Fellowship candidate/member to be promoted directly to rank III and (optionally) a second candidate/member to rank II (more information about the ranks can be found in the Polkadot Fellowship Manifesto)." Could anyone clarify how this should be interpreted in practice? 1. Nominations after Milestone 1. Does this mean that after completing Milestone 1, our team may nominate one person for direct promotion to Rank III, and one person for direct promotion to Rank II? For example: A team member acting as chief architect of our PyJAMaz implementation could be put forward for Rank III, and another team member who architected major subsystems (e.g. PVM, networking, telemetry) could be put forward for Rank II. Is this the correct understanding? 2. Expectations for such Fellowship members: Beyond the general descriptions in the Fellowship Manifesto, are there any additional expectations or aims for members promoted through the JAM Milestone achievement mechanism? For example: Since the milestone work is already remunerated through the JAM Prize, I assume it does not count as Fellowship contribution. But what types of JAM-related activities would be encouraged for Fellowship members? - SDK development? - M1 Delivery peer review? - Broader ecosystem support for the implementation? I’d love to hear if there are already emerging norms or expectations around this especially for teams working on JAM implementations.
# 2025-11-24 23:53 celadari: I'm not sure but I think the work for jam is covered by the fellowship. M1 is a prize and huge part of it is in vested dot and most people need to pay their rent, their food etc Now if you want to advance in the ranks further then I guess more work would be expected 🤔
