We stopped with this activity when the SDK was no longer available for the 0.6.7+ or 0.6.8+ range. I noticed a new release for the PVM Builder was published 6 days ago (https://crates.io/crates/jam-pvm-builder/versions). B. We have a very very very early prototype of a minimal SDK which would allow for Python(esk) built services for JAM/PVM. C. It is not a priority since all our resources are currently in the last mile M1 conformance and M2 Delivery. I doubt we have anything worthwhile ready in February/March for the JAM Course of PBA.

# 2025-11-25 08:58 emielsebastiaan:
# 2025-11-29 10:30 gav: Validators won’t have stakes; there are no plans to use PoS for validator selection.
# 2025-11-29 11:59 gav: Grandpa misbehaviour will be handled in the same way - some logic on the parachains which handles validator selection.
# 2025-11-30 16:07 sourabhniyogi: Ok, we can proceed with implementing GRANDPA with a "all validators have weight 1" approach, no problem, but I clearly have a PoS mind virus: If validators won't have stakes, what are we to slash if there is no stake to slash? Is slashing a $100-200k/yr salary (and maybe a reputation) a sufficient penalty in a new JAM era relative to slashing a $1-2MM stake? What is the status of Phragmen elections and NPoS in a JAM cutover?
# 2025-11-30 23:13 gav: Slashing alone helps only if participants care about the risk. Most validators don’t have much to slash. Nominators don’t care about the risk.
# 2025-12-01 08:23 bkchr: For extra services that we may want to incentivize validator operators to run, how to we want to expose them? The validator IP addresses are stored on chain, should we make this flexible to sort of allows validators to also publish information about extra services they may provide? So, that applications know how to reach these services.
# 2025-12-01 09:38 dave: I think that is the plan. There is a metadata blob for each validator. Currently just contains node address but there's plenty of space for other things there
# 2025-12-01 10:05 hitchhooker: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-tian-quic-quicmls/ https://eprint.iacr.org/2025/2063
# 2025-12-01 10:33 gav: Indeed yes. We might want to increase the size a bit anyway.
# 2025-12-01 10:33 gav: "1KB should be enough for any validator" :) (edited)
# 2025-12-01 10:47 bkchr: > <@gav:polkadot.io> "1KB should be enough for any validator" :) Worst case we probably can just have some "service registry" service registered to discover what the validator offers
# 2025-12-02 00:03 sourabhniyogi: Could we maybe use this 1K to specify features the validator supports, using JIP-{uint} to specify the feature supported? How about adding in a uint before that feature list identifying the JAM implementer client -- defined here or w3f-webops JAM software (validator clients, but not necessarily only that) would be expected to spit out the feature list and their client -- in both cases, matching up to existing github repos for JIP and w3f-webops. This is easy to reason about, and encourages JAM teams to publish experimental JIP-xxxx features that not all JAM clients _must_ implement.
# 2025-12-02 00:38 dave: Not sure about having an implementation identifier as it may encourage people to make decisions based on it. For how bad this can get see eg the User-Agent header. Re identifying features I'm not sure if that makes sense for validators specifically. Validators are supposed to all do the same job, and eg cores rotate around them frequently. In the case of the existing JIPs, whether a validator node implements these or not is only really of concern to the node operator, not to anyone else. JIP-1 should not be enabled on a real validator node; it is for debugging only and enabling it on a real node is almost certainly a security issue (the fixed gas charge is unlikely to be sufficient to cover the actual cost of logging). JIP-2 should _never_ be publicly exposed as it requires the two sides to trust each other. If enabled on a real validator node JIP-3 should only connect to a private telemetry server, it really is not safe to send that information to a third party. It also probably doesn't make sense to do that anyway as it would use a big chunk of your bandwidth. (edited)
# 2025-12-02 01:19 sourabhniyogi: We're going to need a lot less cathedral and a lot more bazaar to get anywhere with this 1K =)
# 2025-12-02 05:14 prasad-kumkar: Hi all! We’re releasing an independent implementation of bandersnatch-vrfs in Python - **Dotring**. If you are interested in testing, reviewing, or integrating it for your implementation, please feel free to reach out! https://github.com/Chainscore/dot-ring Benchmarks - https://github.com/Chainscore/dot-ring/blob/main/docs/BENCHMARK.md Documentation - https://dotring.chainscore.finance Pypi - https://pypi.org/project/dot-ring
# 2025-12-02 05:15 philoniare: Hi everyone, I’m currently integrating our PVM implementation with the accumulation layer. We’re passing all standard PVM tests, but encountering failures specifically in the accumulation tests when our host functions are exercised. Before creating a full suite of custom tests, I wanted to ask whether there are any community-contributed host function call tests available for the PVM. If such tests exist, are they permitted for use under the competition rules?
# 2025-12-03 18:07 danicuki: As far as I know, the existing tests are those in the vectors and conformance tests, which are more like an "acceptance test", other than unit testing each host function.
# 2025-12-03 18:09 danicuki: Talking about tests, are there any test vectors for Paged Proofs, erasure root and other refine (Chapter 14) related stuff?
# 2025-12-03 18:10 dakkk: not yet afaik
# 2025-12-03 19:23 sourabhniyogi: To speed things up, I believe its valuable for us to follow davxy 's example in doing community test vectors for refine, being publishers instead of just subscribers, being proactive rather than just passive. We tried doing this earlier at the start of the year, but in retrospect it was a kindergarten effort relative to the pro-grade effort we've all gone through in jam-test-vectors and jam-conformance the last 6 months. Little test vectors, even if imperfect, from the hungry+unpaid ;) ... would be a fine start as it gets other people learning and doing. Once you get a a few bundles refined you'll want to do this: https://github.com/davxy/jam-conformance/pull/70 and we can compare notes and go pro-grade. I would prefer going full bazaar here with no hand-holding, its really time to grow up. (edited)
# 2025-12-03 19:37 danicuki: If you were in kindergarten 6 months ago, I wasn't even born... 😂 Maybe I am in kindergarten now, eager to catch up and be able to contribute more
# 2025-12-04 13:05 danicuki: I have some doubts about CE-137 - The T function in the Graypaper (H.2) returns just a list of (B U H), while the Justification in the protocol is defined as [0 ++ Hash OR 1 ++ Hash ++ Hash] - Is there anywhere the formal specification for the shard validation, something like fn validate_shard(shard_bin, erasure_root, justification): boolean
# 2025-12-04 14:01 dave: B = Hash ++ Hash in this case, the leaves are pairs of hashes
# 2025-12-04 14:02 dave: The GP formally specifies this stuff
# 2025-12-04 16:45 danicuki:
# 2025-12-04 17:21 danicuki: sure, I am struggling to match the definitions on JAMNSP with the formulas in the GP. We have many things called "Justification" with different meanings: - Formula E.5 J_x is called justification - Formula 14.15 J is called justification - JAMSNP calls T (Formula E.2) justification None of the GP formula mention "pairs of hashes" Sorry if this is a dumb question, all this things are new to me.
# 2025-12-04 17:30 dave: See the definition of u here https://graypaper.fluffylabs.dev/#/ab2cdbd/1c75011c9301?v=0.7.2
# 2025-12-04 17:31 dave: The elements of the list passed into M_B are essentially pairs of hashes
# 2025-12-04 17:32 dave: One of the hashes is the hash of the bundle shard, the other is the root of the tree of segment shards (edited)
# 2025-12-04 17:33 dave: See b^clubs and s^clubs just below
# 2025-12-04 17:34 dave: u is the erasure root and a CE 137 justification is basically a (co)path from one of these hash pairs to the erasure root, it's a fairly regular Merkle proof (edited)
# 2025-12-04 23:31 sourabhniyogi: https://github.com/jam-duna/jamtestnet/issues/139 attempts a tutorial (with diagrams!) -- since nothing has changed on this (?), I believe you could use these as a "can you get the same spec" test case. We can dust up the fuzzer refine features if others were also so inclined. A work report derivation for the jamt circa 0.7.2 would seem to be useful as a small holy grail =) What new CEs (129, 146?, 147?, 148?) have been added in polkajam 0.7.2 that we can check out and confirm alignment on? Are Grandpa CEs 149-153 activatable somehow?
# 2025-12-04 23:57 dave: Ah sorry, not sure we announced the new ones. 147&148 have been added for directly requesting bundles/segments. You don't _need_ to implement these; if a direct request for a bundle/segment fails the requesting node should fall back to recovery via shards. 146 was added to allow builders to provide the content of imported segments, saving the primary guarantor from having to fetch them. Commit that added these protocols here: https://github.com/zdave-parity/jam-np/commit/7c502af98db291bf85d4eb25dc9a8124fd5cc7c8
# 2025-12-04 23:58 dave: Re the Grandpa protocols, these are not yet available in polkajam, but we're starting to merge the grandpa branch into master so hopefully they will be available soonish :)
# 2025-12-05 01:38 sourabhniyogi: This ETH data point reminds me of the following anxiety re "implementation identifier": what if the majority of validators, seeing something like jam-conformance-dashboard in say, 2-3 years from now, overwhelmingly pick the #1 and #2 clients due to performance (lets say spacejam) and reputation (parity, being the eco leader)? I would bet that the end game in JAM client diversity with N clients is extremely unlikely to be anything like 1/N and instead have > 2/3 be on the top #1 / #2 clients in this way. The ETH situation, if you believe this tweets data, is 70% on the top 2, 90% on the top 4. If nothing incentivizes client diversity and continuous competition (e.g. rewards to be in the top 4 clients), wouldn't client diversity tend to gravitate to "winner-take-all" endpoints? At least part why I wanted a byte or two for validator metadata is to not only reward validators ala RFC 119 (who will pick the least buggy clients to give them the most rewards), but also client implementers, who need a sustainable path. Transparency into which validator uses what client, publicly visible performance (even if subjective ala RFC 119), and a sustainable path for client implementers to compete to be in the top 3 to earn some of the validator rewards seems important. Validators _should_ make decisions about which clients to pick based on this transparent information. What am I missing? (edited)
# 2025-12-05 01:42 sourabhniyogi: Why would JAM, following "Strong Web3" principles, want to hide its equivalent of this?
# 2025-12-05 02:46 ascriv: I have similar concerns regarding validator client diversity in the long term, seems like operators will choose from top 1 or 2 most popular/performant, except for perhaps operators who themselves were jam implementors (edited)
# 2025-12-05 04:27 gav: Why would you expect nodes to declare honestly?
# 2025-12-05 06:27 sourabhniyogi: 1. In the beginning, lazy defaults and selfish tech support for validators not run by JAM implementers. JAM implementer teams will not spoof if they are running validators themselves. Since self-staking is gone, I would expect JAM implementer teams to dominate the validator set but quickly fall into some power law distribution where the top 2-4 make up 70-90%. Why would we expect these implementer nodes to declare dishonestly? 2. For client implementations, even with 100% conformance, any actual spoofing attached to xyz public key will be detectable. If reputation relates to honesty down to client bits, spoofing could be frowned upon. 3. Otherwise, I think its naive to expect 100% honesty and would cheer Robin Hood on in taking away from the #1/#2 and giving it to the meritorious #7/#9 esp with client diversity actively valued. A progressive Strong Web3 agenda could justify "dishonestly" spoofing to the point where it becomes 'optimistic funding' for everyones beloved JAM implementers. (edited)
# 2025-12-05 23:17 gav: I agree, it’s naive.
# 2025-12-08 03:40 shimonchick: In accumulation context, do we need the raw/unprocessed work item data? how would we resolve it from the work reports? If i am understanding correctly selector 14 of the host function FETCH needs access to the work item, even in accumulation invocation, right?
# 2025-12-08 12:48 gav: No. Selector 14 is only enabled if bold-i is non-null. Under Accumulation it is null. (edited)
# 2025-12-08 12:55 gav: bold-i doesn't represent the unprocessed data. It represents the _accumulation inputs_. These are either deferred-transfers or operand-tuples (see eq 12.15). (edited)
# 2025-12-09 10:25 davxy: This PR has been mentioned a couple of times in the jam-conformance channel. It covers an important point of ed25519 signatures that could go easily overlooked: https://github.com/davxy/jam-conformance/pull/112 (edited)
# 2025-12-09 11:24 jeff: hehe yay cofactor etc chaos :) (edited)
# 2025-12-09 11:33 jeff: https://hdevalence.ca/blog/2020-10-04-its-25519am/
# 2025-12-10 21:53 danicuki: Hey everyone! 👋 I finally managed to run DOOM on JAM (super fun! https://youtu.be/riyYJo-CKWE?si=cCw5-HIgHnwmvWeH), but I still feel there are some cloudy parts of the workflow. In particular, I’d love help understanding: • How exactly a CoreVM service is created — what’s happening under the hood? • What the builder is really doing — what are the contents/structure of the work packages it keeps submitting? • How to take another arbitrary program/game and make it run on JAM — is there a clear process for compiling something new to PVM and packaging it as a service? How difficult is it supposed to be? Would anyone be open to running a small online workshop or walkthrough for the community? I think a step-by-step session would help a lot of us start experimenting with new ideas and services on JAM. Thanks! 🙏✨
# 2025-12-10 21:57 dave: Not really an answer to your questions _but_ it is possible to look at the source for jamt and CoreVM now, I believe all the crates are on crates.io
# 2025-12-10 22:10 dave: Re compiling something new, it depends if you mean as a JAM service or for CoreVM. For CoreVM you can use https://github.com/paritytech/polkaports, I believe this is how Quake is built although for historical reasons DOOM works a bit differently. If you want to make your own JAM service, the jam-pvm-common crate (https://docs.rs/jam-pvm-common/0.1.26/jam_pvm_common/) is the main crate to look at for Parity's SDK. You can build a PVM blob using jam-pvm-build (https://crates.io/crates/jam-pvm-build). You don't need to use Parity's SDK though, other teams have their own SDKs and you can of course make your own :D
# 2025-12-11 02:26 jaymansfield: The 0.7.2 version of polkajam seems to be using the 0.7.1 value of the WB constant still, at least in in the rpc parameters() call. (Ex: "max_input":13794305)
# 2025-12-11 13:10 dave: What do you mean by the "0.7.2 version"? The nightly release has the correct value AFAIK. Until we start doing real releases I would recommend using the latest nightly build as that should contain all of the latest fixes.
# 2025-12-11 13:35 jaymansfield: Looks like I was using an outdated spec file. Dumping the latest has the right value. Thank you.
# 2025-12-11 13:55 rustybot: Tagged 0.7.2 should have the right WB value as well (edited)
# 2025-12-11 13:11 jaymansfield: I am referring to the latest release supporting GP 0.7.2. Just verified again using nightly-2025-12-11 (edited)
# 2025-12-12 18:28 dave: FYI We've made a minor addition to CE 145: when sending a negative judgment, you now need to include the original guarantee. The guarantee is needed for the dispute to be included in an extrinsic. In the general case the original guarantee not have been seen by all validators, hence the change to distribute it with negative judgments.
# 2025-12-12 18:28 dave: See https://github.com/zdave-parity/jam-np/commit/eb059ddeddc6f14c5bec2929ee5607699f610143
# 2025-12-15 19:49 mkchung: How about jam-np grandpa? Will polkajam support grandpa according to this proposed spec? Our nodes got disconnected from polkajam due to CE 149 not implemented. 
2025-12-15 11:20:49 tokio-runtime-worker DEBUG jam_node::telemetry  PeerMisbehaved { peer: elfaiiixcuzmzroa34lajwp52cdsucikaxdviaoeuvnygdi3imtba, reason: "Unrecognised incoming stream protocol 149" }
2025-12-15 11:20:49 tokio-runtime-worker DEBUG jam_node::telemetry  Disconnected { peer: elfaiiixcuzmzroa34lajwp52cdsucikaxdviaoeuvnygdi3imtba, terminator: Some(Local), reason: "Misbehaviour: Unrecognised incoming stream protocol 149" }
# 2025-12-15 20:03 dave: Yeah the current polkajam release doesn't have these. We're planning to get these enabled soon though...
# 2025-12-15 20:24 mkchung: Can you also clarify CE148 and the meaning of bracket "[]" in the spec? 
Segment Index = u16
Import-Proof = len++[Hash]

Guarantor -> Guarantor

--> [Segments-Root ++ len++[Segment Index]]
--> FIN
<-- [Segment]
<-- [Import-Proof]
<-- FIN
Does [Segments-Root ++ len++[Segment Index]] denote an array of "Segments-Root ++ len++[Segment Index]" -- where each element is Segments-Root ++ len++[Segment Index] such that a guarantor can request segments across multiple Segments-Root in one shot? Or do the brackets [] here simply indicate a "single contiguous byte payload" transmitted during the quick protocol, rather than a list?
# 2025-12-15 20:26 dave: [] means a sequence yeah, guess this is not explicitly stated anywhere 😬
# 2025-12-15 20:26 dave: > a guarantor can request segments across multiple Segments-Root in one shot Yes.
# 2025-12-15 20:48 mkchung: So both CE 139/140 can also be requested with "segments across multiple Segments-Root in one shot" (check?) For CE129, is there an internally enforced maximum response size by polkajam? We attempted to issue a range scan with startKey = 0x00…00 and endKey = 0xff…ff to a PolkaJAM node in order to capture the "true" jam state from polkajam, but the response we received was nowhere near our requested maxSize (10000000 bytes), and more than half of the expected [Key ++ Value] pairs were missing from the response?
# 2025-12-15 20:53 dave: Re 139/140 yes
# 2025-12-15 20:55 dave: Re 129 IIRC yes. You should expect to make multiple requests to fetch a full state. You should preferably spread these over multiple nodes rather than making them all to a single node, when you do this you can even make the requests to different nodes in parallel

# 2025-12-16 20:17 gav: Ivanwould be the man
# 2025-12-17 22:35 emielsebastiaan: It was suggested I repost this here (previously posted in the JAM Conformance channel regarding looking back and looking forward). For what it is worth, we have added a candid JAMdot Technologies retrospective to our milestone 1 delivery submission: https://github.com/w3f/jam-milestone-delivery/blob/ffa56fa241458620362ba9ac957f12ea479590a5/deliveries/jamdottech/pyjamaz-m1.md One key takeaway, in hindsight, is that expectations were set for us that milestone 1 audit submissions would open in Summer of 2025. In practice however, given the significant number of implementation disputes that emerged from Davide Galassi’s conformance fuzzing efforts, none of the teams were anywhere near true milestone 1 conformance at that time. As a result, our team came to view the period from August 2025 through December 2025 as an “informal milestone 1 conformance audit” phase. We are confident that we would not be as far along as we are today without the scrutiny, feedback, and iteration enabled during this period. That said, our team has had extensive and, at times, heated internal discussions around planning, uncertainty, and a shrinking financial runway. In this context, we would appreciate greater clarity on the process for Polkadot Fellowship membership eligibility that follows the achievement of milestone 1 conformance. Based on our reading of the JAM Prize rules, and especially everything we do not know, we assume that two members of our team would be eligible for nomination at Rank II and Rank III, respectively, and that they would be expected to substantiate their eligibility for those ranks based on their concrete contributions. From a financial planning perspective, Fellowship income would materially impact my team's ability to keep the project viable and maintain continuity of work. As such, we seek clarity from a humble and pragmatic standpoint to better align our planning with the realities of that process.
# 2025-12-18 06:27 dhruv245: So, are the actual date of M1 submission released?
# 2025-12-18 07:41 emielsebastiaan: Tentative January 2026 according to the Jam Conformance channel as per W3F. https://matrix.to/#/!ksYpYHcVftKsUAsdMa%3Amatrix.org/%24VXT64xEqhGvT0eg457HPgvjG29tW8MzmP7flEQN1cps (edited)
# 2025-12-18 09:38 gav: As per the prize rules, M1 conformant implementations get to up-rank a team-member to rank III, disregarding the usual time requirements. It does not alter the other requirements of members; the individual claiming the up-rank will be expected to be an expert in their implementation and how it relates to the spec. The rank III defence is always done in person and the individual will be challenged to demonstrate knowledge, understanding, personal development and ethos in line with the Fellowship Manifesto. In general, I would expect that the team nominate the individual who is most knowledgable about both the Graypaper and their code. M1 conformance does not guarantee a rank, only the right to skip the time requirement. If there is no single individual who can fulfil the relevant requirements then a team may be unable to claim the concession. I can’t imagine this would happen much, but it may be the case where a team has deconstructed agency to an assembly-line level and splits apart Graypaper comprehension, code architecture and code writing. I’d also expect to find it if a team overused LLMs to create their codebase. The Fellowship induction/ process for rank II is generally not done in person and has substantially lesser requirements overall than for rank III. In terms of timing, I can’t speak for other high ranking members, but I’ll make myself available for the in-person defence as a priority once an M1 compliant implementer comes forward. Finally, note that the Fellowship is a collective of humans. Teams, per se, have no representation in it. (edited)
# 2025-12-18 17:06 prasad-kumkar: Hey all, I’m sharing an IDE playground we’ve been working on - jamcode.fun - for building, deploying and invoking services on JAM . It works on a simulated execution environment, we’re testing this on live networks (localnet and a deployed tiny testnet) for services to be deployed and invoked realtime, but it’s a bit unstable for now. We integrated our team’s SDK in C, C++ and Python, next we look to integrate jade Tianyi | SpaceJam, jam-brains Oliver Tale-Yazdi - OOO and jam-sdk davxy. Though it's quite early stage at the moment, simulation supports limited host calls and Python is transpiled (making it very restrictive). We’ll likely have a more usable deployment in the coming weeks or months. Appreciate any feedback! If anyone wants to integrate their SDK or testnet, please ping me.
# 2025-12-18 17:33 clearloop: interesting, online IDE would be good for template/example sharing + quick view of the virtual machine, please feel free to ping me if meet any problems with jade

# 2025-12-22 11:54 gav: There is no specification on that front because there doesn’t need to be one.
# 2025-12-22 11:54 gav: It is explicitly designed to have a result independent of an implementation’s compute order. (edited)
# 2025-12-22 13:24 harpreetgill: Hi everyone, I have a question regarding the in-built PVM provided by JAM/Polkadot. Can we use this in-built PVM to build M1 and M2? If yes, does that mean such a project would only be eligible for submission under a non-PVM track, since we are not implementing a custom PVM ourselves? I had asked a similar question earlier, but I wanted to clarify this distinction more precisely.
# 2025-12-22 13:27 dave: M1 and M2 submissions must use your own PVM implementation even for the non-PVM validating node path. You can use a third-party PVM implementation for M3 (performance milestone)
# 2025-12-22 13:30 dave: It's probably fine to integrate a third-party PVM for M1/M2 development/testing, but for the actual submission the PVM needs to be your own. It can be a simple interpreter, doesn't need to be blazing fast
# 2025-12-22 13:34 dhruv245: For M1 and M2 submission in both Validating Node Path and Non-PVM Validating Node Path: Can we use this JAM service, the jam-pvm-common crate (https://docs.rs/jam-pvm-common/0.1.26/jam_pvm_common/) For submission?
# 2025-12-22 13:41 dave: That crate is for developing JAM services. You're welcome to use it to make services for testing your node implementation if that's what you mean?
# 2025-12-22 13:45 dhruv245: Ok, basically right now we have completed everything. Fuzzer is roughly 5 ms We have used this PVM Service jam-pvm-common crate (https://docs.rs/jam-pvm-common/0.1.26/jam_pvm_common/) So 1)You are saying the above service is for testing only and we need a create a PVM from start for submission of M1/M2 submission for both Validating Node Path and Non-PVM Validating Node Path 2) Then what is the difference between Validating Node Path and Non-PVM Validating Node Path submission.
# 2025-12-22 13:46 dhruv245: David Emett:
# 2025-12-22 13:47 dave: I'm not sure what you mean honestly. jam-pvm-common is not a service and I'm not sure why you would use it in your node implementation -- it is not use by PolkaJam for example.
# 2025-12-22 13:48 dave: You do need to create your own PVM implementation yes, but jam-pvm-common is not a PVM implementation?
# 2025-12-22 13:49 dave: For details on the different paths (validating, non-PVM validating & light client) please see this page: https://jam.web3.foundation/
# 2025-12-22 13:49 dhruv245: Like you have mentioned here
# 2025-12-22 13:50 dave: I was talking about developing JAM services there, the milestones are for JAM node implementations not JAM services
# 2025-12-23 08:57 ascriv: Could we please have some clarity on how exactly "half speed" and "full speed" will be measured for M3/M4? Would be useful to determine if/when I need to write a rust pvm (edited)
# 2025-12-23 10:07 gav: It will be based on how fast the implementation can do certain network-observable reactions (ie patterns of JAMNP messages received & sent and how long it takes between a series of messages received and sending on correct onward messages). Practically speaking it will likely be a simple timing component added to the M2 conformance tests. Both M3 and M4 times will be provided for various reactions. M4 should be in line with the need for Polkadot and a network with M4 nodes should, by definition, be able to run full speed. M3 will simply be a lesser target with the aim of still being useful (eg for Kusama) but only needing (very roughly) half of the work. The specific times for M4 have yet to be determined, but will in part be based on PolkaJAM and potentially other high-performance implementations, especially in areas where response time is a bottleneck to overall emergent network performance. Where we can relax times and still expect full network-level throughput, we will, to avoid the need for teams to match other implementations’ performance across the board. For present purposes, PolkaJAM may be used as a reasonable target for that behaviour. M2 conformance is where relevant Parity efforts are currently being focussed. Once this is done it should be a relatively short hop to M3&4 performance tests.
# 2025-12-25 06:08 hitchhooker:
# 2025-12-30 11:05 danicuki: I have a doubt about Work-package submission (CE-133): - the submission includes a "Core Index" information. What happens if the receiver guarantor does not belongs to this core (by the core assignment rule (Formula 11.21)? - Is the builder responsible for knowing to each validator it should send the work package? In this case, what criteria the builder uses to choose which of the 3 possible validators?
# 2026-01-01 11:54 dave: You should allow a bit of leeway but if the core is not currently assigned to you then you can just close the stream with an error
# 2026-01-01 11:57 dave: Yes, the builder needs to decide which validator to send to. Picking randomly amongst the 3 assigned is a good start but obviously you may want to fall back to one of the others if submitting to the first randomly selected one doesn't work
# 2026-01-05 13:17 igankevich: This error means that the program blob lacks metadata. I've updated polkaports to fix the issue. Simply pull the repo and run setup & quake compilation steps again. You might need to run make clean in quake directory to remove old program blob.

# 2026-01-18 18:48 celadari: Hi all, quick clarification regarding prize payments. From email exchanges about ~1.5 years ago, we had the impression that prizes being paid out to individual team members’ addresses shouldn't be a problem. However, reading the current T&Cs (https://github.com/w3f/jam-milestone-delivery/blob/main/docs/T%26Cs.md), specifically section 8.5, it seems to suggest that only a single address can be provided for payment. Can someone from the W3F please confirm whether: - multiple recipient addresses (one per team member) are acceptable ? - or if indeed prizes must now be paid to a single address only ? Thanks in advance for the clarification
# 2026-01-20 20:42 sourabhniyogi: Any news on https://polkadot.academy/jam/ being held this Spring?
# 2026-01-21 14:15 shimonchick: is it possible to create and export a work package to json using jamt for refinement testing purposes? or do i need to explicitly implement the rpc server to handle further conversions? Or maybe there is a simpler method? (edited)
# 2026-01-21 18:28 dave: You don't _have_ to implement RPC. The intent with RPC is that you use it to talk to a regular (ie non-validator) node running on the same machine and then this node uses SNP to talk to JAM to actually submit packages for example. You can just use polkajam (or some other node which has an RPC impl) for this intermediate node if you haven't implemented RPC yourself. All the validator nodes can use your node impl
# 2026-01-21 18:29 dave: FWIW I don't think jamt has a way of exporting things as JSON but I'm not an expert on it
# 2026-01-22 16:04 danicuki: > <@shimonchick:matrix.org> is it possible to create and export a work package to json using jamt for refinement testing purposes? or do i need to explicitly implement the rpc server to handle further conversions? Or maybe there is a simpler method? I would say that implementing RPC is quite trivial (once you already have JAMSNP) and worth the invested time. You don’t need to implement all methods, only those you think are useful for your debugging (even if at some point you will need most of them).
# 2026-01-28 13:49 emielsebastiaan: This feels like one of those achievements towards M2 you need to share: PyJAMaz has achieved DOOM! https://x.com/jamdottech/status/2016506194710401468?s=46&t=ThX7Y87rr1MIKyk6af4OXg
# 2026-01-29 10:21 bamzedev: For M1 submission do we need to have Ancestry enabled or it's not mandatory atm?
# 2026-01-29 11:26 olanod: Any team working on a pvm recompiler for aarch64 and/or riscv64 hosts or thinking of adding support for it?
# 2026-01-29 11:37 dave: I believe there is a plan to support aarch64 in the polkavm recompiler eventually, but AFAIK this is not currently being worked on. Jan Bujak may have more to add. FWIW the gas costs are being set based on the x86 machines in the toaster, unsure if these will be appropriate for any current aarch64 machines.
# 2026-01-29 11:55 jaymansfield: JavaJAMs recompiler supports both aarch64/x86. I actually started with aarch64 as it was a bit easier with the additional registers. I added in x86 instructions afterwards. (edited)
# 2026-01-29 12:47 jan: I will be adding an aarch64 backend to PolkaVM once I'm done with all of the higher priority work (which will take quite some time). That said, the current official reference hardware for JAM is the Toaster, so the expectation is that you will need to have an amd64 recompiler, and any aarch64 recompiler you might have will not be evaluated in any way. Depending on how it's written and on what hardware you're running it may or may not be conformant with JAM's gas cost model.
# 2026-01-29 12:52 jan: Also, FYI while I'm here - if you're using any of my tooling (e.g. polkatool link etc.) then you should temporarily pin it to version 0.29.0. Newer versions include some changes which are incompatible with GP 0.7.x. (Once GP 0.8.0 is out you can switch back to the newest version since I've recently introduced explicit versioning of the ISA so any potential incompatible changes will be isolated from the JAM-specific ISA.) (edited)
